Kunming Yunnan 650101 China cYunnan Copper Co., Ltd., Kunming, Yunnan 650101, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 Yue Wang, (2000-), F(Han), Luzhou, Sichuan, China, studying for M.S. under the supervision of Prof. Xiaohua Yu, engaged in the research of air battery catalysts. 2 Mainly engaged in the research of non-ferrous metallurgy. Perovskite/carbon composites have received extensive attention in the field of electrocatalysis due to their outstanding catalytic activity and good electrical conductivity. These materials have the advantages of structural stability and low cost and exhibit excellent catalytic performance in electrocatalytic reactions. In this paper, we first review the progress of research on perovskite oxide materials. We discussed its modification strategies in electrocatalysis, including crystal structure adjustment, doping regulation, nano-treatment and carbon material composite. Then, the specific application examples of three leading perovskite/carbon composites in electrocatalytic reactions are summarized, showing these composites' good performance and high efficiency in the catalytic process. Finally, the development trend of perovskite/carbon composites as electrocatalyst carriers is comprehensively summarized and prospected, which points out the future research direction for promoting its application and development in clean energy. Graphical abstract This paper focuses on the modification methods of perovskite and the research progress of perovskite / carbon composites obtained by carbon materials in the field of electrocatalysis. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Perovskite Carbon Oxygen reduction Oxygen evolution Clean energy Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction With the continuous development of human society, the energy demand has risen sharply, and excessive consumption has sounded the alarm. Sustainable development has become the core issue of modern society [1,2]. Electrochemical energy conversion and storage equipment is critical to the global energy transition from fossil energy to clean and renewable energy, which is essential for the future energy structure [3,4]. Electrocatalytic technology has become a hot research field because of its mild reaction conditions, environmental protection and cleanliness. It can realize the conversion of electrical and chemical energy using redox reactions, producing clean energy and degrading pollutants. Therefore, it shows broad application potential in surface engineering, environmental protection, chemical power supply, corrosion-resistant materials and medical treatment [5]. Electrocatalytic technology mainly includes hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). In fuel cells and metal-air batteries, ORR is a cathodic reaction, while OER is an anodic reaction in the process of water electrolysis. The kinetic engineering of these two reactions is relatively slow, and efficient catalysts are needed to reduce the reaction activation energy and increase the reaction rate. Therefore, these two reactions are the focus of current research. Electrocatalytic materials can be divided into three types: noble metal-based, transition metal oxide, and carbon-based. Precious metals such as platinum (Pt), iridium (Ir) and ruthenium (Ru) have excellent electrocatalytic activity. Still, due to their high cost and limited reserves, this has formed a specific restriction in large-scale production and application. Many non-noble metal catalysts have become attractive air catalysts due to their low cost and high catalytic activity [6]. The low cost of perovskite and the good balance between activity and stability make it a promising catalyst for electrochemical devices that require dual functions [7–9]. Compared with noble metal catalysts, these materials exhibit disadvantages such as poor intrinsic activity, limited specific surface area, and relatively low apparent catalytic activity [10]. As an efficient and stable metal-free electrocatalyst, carbon-based composites can be stable in acidic media for a long time. Carbon-based composites also have good catalytic performance as electrocatalysts for oxygen evolution reactions in alkaline media [11]. However, it is accompanied by problems such as carbon oxidation under OER conditions and the failure of ORR sites that need to be further overcome. To overcome these limitations, it is urgent to develop OER/ORR catalysts with low cost, abundant reserves and high activity and stability in alkaline solutions [12]. Researchers usually combine the characteristics of easy adjustment of elements and controllable activity to improve perovskite-based oxides' physical and chemical properties through various modification methods. The catalytic activity and stability of perovskite-based oxides in oxygen reduction/oxygen evolution reaction (ORR/OER) can be improved by adjusting crystal structure, doping, nano-treatment and compounding with carbon materials. Among them, carbon material composite is the focus of current research. Perovskite/carbon composites have great potential in the field of electrocatalysis due to their good conductivity, high specific surface area, adjustable catalytic performance, excellent stability, versatility, and low cost. Carbon materials (such as graphene, carbon nanotubes, and MXene) can significantly improve the conductivity of perovskite, promote electron transport, and provide more reaction sites, thereby increasing the catalytic reaction rate. In addition, the catalytic activity can be optimized by composition adjustment and metal ion doping. The combination of thermal stability and chemical stability of perovskite with carbon materials enhances the long-term stability of composite materials, adapts to a variety of electrocatalytic reactions, is cost-effective, and meets the requirements of sustainable development. 2 The current research status of perovskite Perovskite is a massive crystal known as calcium titanate (CaTiO3), found in the Russian Ural Mountains in 1839 and named after the Russian geologist Lev Perovski [13,14]. Nowadays, perovskite generally refers to compounds with the above structure or distorted structure [15]. Its chemical formula is ABX3, wherein the A-site is a cation with a larger radius, such as alkali metal, alkaline earth metal and rare earth metal ions; the B-site is a relatively small cation, such as transition metal ions; x is an anion, such as halogen or oxyanion [16]. Among these perovskite structures, ABO3 type structure is more common [17]. Many functional materials, such as ferroelectric ceramics, fuel cell electrodes and solar cell materials, have this structure. In 1972, Tseung [18] et al. noticed that the O2 molecule contained pairs of electrons and was paramagnetic, so they explored the electrode behaviour of oxygen on perovskite-type oxides such as La0.5Sr0.5CoO3 and obtained an open-circuit electrode potential close to the thermodynamic equilibrium potential of oxygen. This discovery has led to extensive interest in perovskite-type oxides as electrode catalysts by many electrochemical workers. Then, many researchers have prepared perovskite oxides such as LaCoO3[19–21], SrCoO3 [22,23], and LaFeO3 [24] by different methods, which proved that they have good catalytic activity in oxygen reduction reactions. Oxygen-related electrochemical processes, such as oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), are mostly kinetically sluggish reactions, which affect the overall efficiency of energy storage and conversion devices [25]. Perovskite-type materials with flexible crystal and electronic structures have been studied for a long time. They are widely used in oxygen-related electrocatalytic reactions, including electrochemical water splitting, metal-air batteries and solid oxide fuel cells (Fig. 1, Table 1 ). Wang H [26] et al. synthesized perovskite LaCoO3 by polymer-assisted method and introduced cationic defects at its A-site, which effectively improved the electrocatalytic activity of OER and ORR. The bifunctionality of the prepared electrocatalyst is significantly enhanced. Its bifunctionality is equal to and even better than the original LaCoO3, and many advanced reported electrocatalysts, including perovskite and noble metal electrocatalysts. This indicates that the material is expected to be an ideal choice for bifunctional electrocatalysts in oxygen electrochemical devices such as fuel cells and metal-air batteries. The rechargeable zinc-air battery assembled by A-site defect (SmSr)0.95Co0.9Pt0.1O3 perovskite prepared by EDTA-citric acid complexation method by Wang C [27] et al. showed good discharge potential and charge potential, respectively, with high stability. The electrocatalytic decomposition of water to produce hydrogen, namely hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), is an attractive method to convert the electrical energy generated by renewable energy into chemical energy stored in hydrogen molecules [28]. Jayavelu Y [29] first explored the synthesis of tungsten (W) 1 % doped BaSnO by a simple hydrogen peroxide pathway as an electrocatalyst for HER activity in acidic media, which not only obtained the durability and performance of hydrogen evolution activity but also confirmed the enhancement of the initial current density of W-doped BaSnO samples. Perovskite oxides are promising functional materials for efficient and cost-effective electrocatalysts to replace traditional platinum/carbon catalysts. Although perovskite materials exhibit good catalytic performance in electrocatalytic reactions, unfortunately, most perovskite materials still show relatively low intrinsic activity. This low intrinsic activity limits their application in high-efficiency catalytic applications, especially in fuel cells and other energy conversion fields. Therefore, exploring and implementing effective activation strategies to improve the intrinsic activity of perovskite structure is very important, and this is a key topic in the current related research field. 3 Catalytic activity modification strategy of perovskite materials Perovskite oxides, such as LaCoO3 and LaMnO3, have shown great application potential in air batteries due to their stable structure, adjustable activity, diverse element selection and low cost. However, although the basic perovskite has good stability, its activity could be better. Therefore, appropriate improvement measures are often necessary to improve its performance and meet the needs of air battery applications [30]. There are many methods to enhance the activity of perovskite-type oxygen reduction catalysts, including crystal structure adjustment, doping regulation, nano-treatment and carbon material compounding. 3.1 Crystal structure adjustment The crystal structure adjustment has proven to be an effective strategy for improving the electrocatalytic performance of perovskite oxides. At present, the crystal and surface properties of perovskite electrocatalysts can be modified by adjusting the sintering temperature of the crystal to improve the catalytic performance of ORR and OER. The crystal structure of perovskite-based oxides is one of the key factors affecting their electrocatalytic performance. Adjusting the preparation method of perovskite oxides can cause changes in their crystal structure, morphology, surface properties and internal defects, thus affecting the catalytic performance of electrocatalysts [31]. The crystal structure adjustment covers the defect regulation, in-situ desolvation, lattice strain regulation and microstructure regulation of perovskite oxides. The commonly used preparation methods of perovskite materials can be used to adjust the crystal structure of perovskite oxides. Xie J [32] et al. synthesized nickel-substituted LaMnO3 perovskite oxide LaNi0.3Mn0.7O3 (SG LNM-3) with balanced bifunctional ORR and OER intrinsic activity by sol-gel method. The one-dimensional nanostructure LaNi0.3Mn0.7O3 (ES LNM-3) prepared by electrospinning has a larger specific surface area, a continuous electron transfer pathway, and a bifunctional activity far exceeding SG LNM-3. As shown in Fig. 2 , in addition to the morphological effect, the high spin Mn3+, low spin Ni3+, and high Jahn-Teller distortion are the reasons for the high activity of ES LNM-3. Chen H [33] systematically studied the OER and ORR bifunctional properties of LaCoO3, including the surface reconstruction and distortion-related bifunctional mechanism (DRBM) of LaCoO3 surface, and revealed the surface reconstruction-induced DRBM mechanism, which is characterized by direct O-O coupling and dissociation. When Li X [34] equals the perovskite structure, the Sr cation and O anion defects in the SrxVO3-δ material are fine-tuned to obtain higher specific / area/volume capacity, superior rate capability and excellent cycle stability. The results show that the maximum capacity of SrxVO3-δ reaches 444 mAh g-1, which is 37 % higher than that of chemically measured SrVO3, and the entire battery can achieve more than 6000 discharge/charge cycles with a capacity retention rate of 80 %. Li N [35] used two complex peroxides, La0.6Sr0.4Co0.8Fe0.2O3-δ (LSCF) and Ba0.5Sr0.5Co0.8Fe0.2O3-δ (BSCF), as examples to illustrate that the double cation defect introduction method of A1 and A2 can improve the activity and stability. The electrochemical measurement results reveal that after optimization, both A-LSCF10 and A-BSCF10 show extremely excellent OER catalytic activity, and their performance is remarkable. It has considerable application potential and research value in related fields. Although the adjustment of the crystal structure can effectively lead to significant changes in the crystal structure, morphology, surface properties and internal defects of perovskite-type oxides, which has an essential impact on the catalytic performance of electrocatalysts, the related preparation processes are often complicated in practical applications. This complexity increases the technical difficulty in the production process and leads to higher production costs, which limits the wide application and commercialization of such materials to a certain extent. 3.2 Doping regulation Due to the restriction of crystal structure tolerance, in ABO3 perovskite oxides, the A site is usually occupied by elements with larger atomic radii, such as lanthanide elements [36]. In LMnO3 (L: La, Pr, Nd, Sm, Gd) -based perovskites, the larger the atomic radius, the higher the oxygen reduction catalytic activity. For LaMO3 (M: Ni, Co, Fe, Mn, Cr) -based perovskites, the ORR activity from high to low is LaCoO3 > LaMnO3 > LaNiO3 > LaFeO3 > LaCrO3[37]. However, in practice, the A and B sites of ABO3-type perovskite oxides are not only occupied by a single element. The addition of doping elements can change the crystal structure, electronic structure and catalytic activity of perovskite oxides, and the different elemental compositions of A and B sites will also change the catalytic oxidation activity of the catalyst to a certain extent [38]. For perovskite, the B-site ion dominates the catalytic activity, and the A-site ion radius and electronegativity also have some influence. and the A-site ion can adjust the valence state of the B-site ion and stabilize the structure. Element doping is an important method to modify perovskite oxide (ABO3) electrocatalysts. Li K [39] studied the performance of several Sr0.75Pr0.25Fe1-xCoxO3-δ (x = 0,0.25,0.5,0.75,1) in alkaline environment. The doping of cobalt element can promote the O 2p band center to move in the positive direction, which increases the number of electrons around the Fermi level, thereby improving the conductivity. When part of Co replaces Fe, it will promote the surface remodeling process, resulting in an increase in the number of active sites, and ultimately improve the catalytic activity. The A / B-site doping method is highly versatile and easy to operate, which is a key way to deeply understand and develop effective perovskite oxides for zinc-air battery electrodes (Fig. 3 ). In addition, Zhou H [40] et al. prepared a series of La1-xBaxCoO3 (x = 0,0.05,0.10,0.15,0.20) perovskite oxides, which proved that the doping of Ba increased the specific surface area of the catalyst, which could provide more active centers and make the electron and material transfer faster. The perovskite structure Sr0.9M0.1RuO3-δ (SMRO, M = K, Na, Ag) synthesized by Wang Y [41] et al.by the sol-gel method has excellent bifunctional catalytic activity. With metal ions (M+) doping at the A site, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis showed that oxygen vacancies and lattice oxygen were introduced into the structure, which was confirmed to be the main reason for the improvement of catalytic activity. The electrochemical data of more doped modified perovskite oxide (ABO3) electrocatalysts are shown in Table 2 . The doping of A and B sites is usually based on the stoichiometric ratio of raw materials. The selection of appropriate doping elements is easy to implement and has a low cost, which has become the preferred strategy for material modification. The O-site doping requires a specific high-temperature heat treatment. Although this method is slightly costly, it poses a challenge to the feasibility of large-scale production. Researchers are also exploring a variety of doping element combinations to optimize catalytic performance. Nevertheless, the potential advantages of O-site doping have attracted increasing attention, and more research may focus on this in the future to improve the performance of perovskite-type oxides in electrocatalytic reactions. 3.3 Nano-treatment Nano-treatment has been proven to be an effective strategy to improve the bifunctional catalytic activity of perovskite-based oxide electrocatalysts, mainly due to its high specific surface area and clear pore structure. These unique properties not only facilitate efficient electron transport and oxygen transfer processes but also give stability to specific oxygen-containing intermediates, thereby significantly enhancing the performance of electrocatalysts as a whole, and have a very critical role and far-reaching research value in the field of related energy conversion and catalytic reactions [47]. Perovskite nanostructures have unique properties, such as large surface area, extensive porous structure, controllable transport and charge carrier mobility, strong absorption and photoluminescence, and confinement effects. These characteristics, coupled with the unique adjustability of their composition, shape and function, make perovskite nanocrystals very effective in energy-related applications such as photovoltaics, catalysts, thermoelectrics, batteries, supercapacitors, and hydrogen storage systems [48,49]. The difficulty in realizing nanoporous perovskite electrocatalysts lies in the precise design of nanostructured materials' morphology, particle size, surface properties and porosity [50]. SrNb0.1Co0.7Fe0.2O3-δperovskite nanorods (SNCF-NRs) prepared by the electrospinning method by Zhu Y [51] et al. exhibited excellent OER and HER activity and stability in an alkaline solution environment, which benefited from the catalytic properties of perovskite itself and its unique structural characteristics. When SNCF-NR is used as an anode and a cathode catalyst in an alkaline water electrolysis cell, the current density reaches 10 mA cm-2. The cell voltage is only about 1.68 V. This process also maintains excellent durability, which gives the material great potential for application and research value in related fields such as water electrolysis and hydrogen production. It is expected to provide strong technical support and material guarantees for developing and utilizing clean energy (Fig. 4 ). Jiao Xie [52] et al. prepared a one-dimensional nanostructure LaNi0.3Mn0.7O3 (ES LNM-3) to improve the apparent activity of the material further. The optimized ES LNM-3 has a higher specific surface area and a continuous electron transfer pathway, and the bifunctional activity is significantly improved. Good electrochemical performance was obtained when assembled in a zinc-air battery. Nandhakumar E [53] et al. used lemon extract as a reducing and blocking agent for metal ions to prepare highly uniform hexagonal LaCoO3 nanosheets and GdCoO3 nanorods. GdCoO3 exhibits more muscular OER activity due to its one-dimensional structure. In addition, these results indicate that perovskite-based nanostructures can be used as OER electrocatalysts in water electrolysis. Nanomaterials give the material a high specific surface area and clear pore structure, promote efficient electron and oxygen transfer processes, and provide stability for specific oxygen-containing intermediates. However, the traditional synthesis methods have the disadvantages of large particle size and unclear morphological characteristics. Preparing nano-perovskite materials with high uniformity and low defects is complicated to control in different batches. In composite materials or heterostructures, the interface properties between nano-perovskite materials and other materials may cause energy loss and interface mismatch, affecting the catalytic performance. The high specific surface area of nanomaterials makes them more susceptible to oxygen and water, which reduces their stability in practical applications. 3.4 Carbon material compounding The ORR reaction of pure carbon materials is mainly along the two-electron pathway, with high overpotential, and the catalytic performance could be better than that of noble metal catalysts [54]. Carbon materials are easy to corrode, but their conductivity and high surface area are required to obtain efficient catalysts. Alegre C [55] prepared a perovskite/carbon composite catalyst by mixing perovskite La0.6Sr0.4Fe0.8Co0.2O3 (LSFCO) with a high surface area carbon black and compared it with a Pd/C catalyst. The results showed that the ORR activity of LSFCO was lower than that of Pd/C, but the OER activity was significantly higher than that of Pd/C. In addition, the catalyst of LSFCO showed more substantial stability in the charge-discharge cycle (Fig. 5 ). Forming a perovskite/carbon composite material to introduce a perovskite carbon interface will likely promote a synergistic effect between the two phases, strengthening the ORR / OER performance. On the one hand, carbon materials can increase the electrochemical area and improve the conductivity. At the same time, carbon materials are also easy to construct porous structures, thereby accelerating the mass transfer process; on the other hand, carbon-based materials, especially carbon-based single-atom materials, have high ORR activity. Combined with OER active substances, they are easy to exhibit bifunctional characteristics. In the standard perovskite/carbon composites, the carbon phase constructs a conductive network, electrically connects the perovskite particles, and optimizes the electrical contact between the perovskite phase and the electrode to ensure that the utilization rate of perovskite in the ORR / OER electrocatalytic process reaches the maximum [56]. Many studies have confirmed that with the addition of carbon, the ORR / OER activity of perovskite will be significantly enhanced [57]. Xiao P [58] et al. designed perovskite-type oxide-carbon composites (LaFeO3_N) for catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) of furfural to furfuryl alcohol, providing two key steps to ensure that the reactants can be supplied to the active site in time for the reaction. The results show that the reaction rate of the composites is 6 times that of the carbon-free materials. This strategy to improve the catalytic performance of perovskite oxides can be easily applied to other low-surface-area catalytic systems. Therefore, metal oxide perovskite-carbon material composites are potential substitutes for precious metal-based materials. Currently, the carbon materials commonly used in composite mainly include graphene, carbon nanotubes, MXene, etc. The preparation of perovskite/carbon composites in the literature is roughly divided into two categories: (1) perovskite/carbon composites prepared by physical mixing and (2) In-situ chemical synthesis of perovskite/carbon hybrids [56,59]. Most of the perovskite/carbon composites prepared by physical mixing disperse carbon materials on the surface of perovskite by ball milling. However, there are few reports on in-situ chemical synthesis of perovskite/carbon hybrids. This is because the preparation process of perovskite materials requires calcination. Calcination in the air will pyrolyze carbon materials. Calcination under the protection of inert gas will also destroy the perovskite structure due to the redox reaction between perovskite and carbon materials. Table 3 shows the performance data of some perovskite / carbon composites prepared by two methods. Therefore, choosing a suitable preparation method can make perovskite/carbon composites more widely used in the field of electrocatalysis (Fig. 6 ). The perovskite material has good stability, and the carbon material has a rich pore structure. The combination of the two is a ' strong combination ' modification strategy. This method can not only give full play to the high activity of perovskite materials in the electrocatalytic process but also utilize the excellent conductivity of carbon materials to integrate the advantages of the two to achieve a synergistic effect. This synergistic effect is particularly significant in enhancing the performance of oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). This modification strategy can not only solve the shortcomings of a single material but also open up new ideas and directions for developing and applying electrocatalytic devices and promote the further development of catalytic materials in energy conversion and storage. 4 Electrocatalytic application of perovskite / carbon composites 4.1 Application of perovskite-graphene composites in electrocatalysis Graphene is a two-dimensional material composed of carbon honeycombs and is considered one of the most promising electrocatalyst materials. Compared with other carbon materials, graphene has high thermal and electrical conductivity, high theoretical specific surface area, and adjustable electronic and morphological structure [65]. Graphene-based materials exhibit many available active sites due to their ultra-thin open structure and large specific surface area, making them particularly prominent in high-efficiency electrocatalysis [54,66]. On the one hand, doping atoms and defects in the graphene skeleton can enhance its electrocatalytic activity. On the other hand, graphene and its based materials can be used as metal-based catalyst support to promote electron transfer and synergistically improve catalytic performance [67]. At present, graphene and its structurally optimized derivatives are widely used to improve the electrochemical performance of monoclonal antibodies. Usually, ideal graphene crystals exhibit inertness in many catalytic reactions, but defects and heteroatoms can significantly enhance their activity in various electrocatalytic responses [68] (Fig. 7). Molina-García M A [69] et al. first studied the dual-doped graphene/perovskite mixture as an oxygen reduction catalyst. SN-Gr/LSM, PN-Gr/LSM and BN-Gr/LSM catalysts were prepared by co-reduction of boron, nitrogen, phosphorus and sulphur precursors with graphene oxide and mixing with strontium lanthanum manganate (LSM). In addition, double-doped graphene, graphene, LSM and commercial Pt/C were used as controls. The addition of LSM to dual-doped graphene can significantly improve its catalytic performance. The optimized composition ratio can make PN-Gr/LSM reach 85 % of the commercial Pt/C current density at 0.6 V (vs. Ag/AgCl). Nam-In Kim [70] et al. found that the double perovskite structure NdBa0.5Sr0.5Co1.5Fe0.5O5+δ (NBSCF) has an oxygen activity of 0.973 V, which is much higher than the previously reported transition metal-based nanostructures and is also superior to precious metal electrocatalysts. Qin S P [71] et al. prepared SrCoO3 perovskite catalysts by loading graphene and doping Mn. The ORR catalytic activity of SrCo0.5Mn0.5O3 loaded with 20 % graphene was significantly improved. The interfacial interaction between graphene and SrCoO3 increases the peak potential of ORR reaction, but there is no interaction between graphene and SrCo0.5Mn0.5O3 interface. The graphene-loaded SrCo0.5Mn0.5O3 perovskite catalyst exhibits excellent electrocatalytic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) activity and is suitable as a cathode catalyst for aluminum-air batteries. Wang X [72] et al. developed a simple sol-gel method to directly grow perovskite La0.5Sr0.5Co0.8Fe0.2O3−δ (LSCF) on the surface of reduced graphene oxide (rGO). Among them, LSCF@rGO-0.5 exhibits the best bifunctional catalytic activity and performs well in zinc-air batteries. In the electrocatalytic process, the rapid transfer of electrons is the key to an efficient reaction. Graphene effectively reduces the electron transport impedance and ensures the smooth progress of the catalytic reaction. Its high specific surface area and abundant reaction sites greatly enhance the catalyst's reactivity. By changing the structure of graphene or adjusting its composite with perovskite oxides, researchers can effectively alter the electrochemical properties of the catalyst. This adjustment ability makes the catalyst exhibit better performance under specific reaction conditions, and it can be optimized in different reaction systems to improve adaptability. Therefore, graphene-supported perovskite oxide electrocatalysts have significant energy conversion and storage advantages. 4.2 Application of perovskite-carbon nanotube composites in electrocatalysis Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) were accidentally discovered by Iijima, a Japanese electron microscope expert when observing spherical carbon molecules produced by graphite arc equipment with high-resolution transmission electron microscopy. It is a sp2 orbital hybrid tubular structure formed by a curling graphite sheet structure [73]. Due to the unique structure of CNTs, they have excellent carbon material properties. At the same time, it also has the electrical and thermal conductivity of metals, the heat resistance and corrosion resistance of ceramic materials, the weaving performance similar to textile fibres, and is lightweight and easy to process. It is a high-strength carbon fibre material with great potential and significant application requirements in commercial and industrial fields. It has attracted wide attention from researchers at home and abroad [74–77] (Fig. 8). Sui [78] et al. combined the 'dissolution effect ' of perovskite oxides at high temperature and reducing atmosphere to synthesize carbon nanotubes (CNTs) in situ on the surface of La0.8Sr1.2Fe0.5Ni0.5 perovskite oxides with K2NiF4 structure. Its cycle stability is better in more than 3000 cycles than commercial IrO2 catalysts and published perovskite-type bifunctional oxygen catalysts. Therefore, constructing perovskite oxide/carbon composites with close interaction at the interface significantly improves electrical conductivity and bifunctional oxygen activity. Karina Elumeeva [79] et al. directly grew nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes on the surface of Co-and Fe-containing perovskites. Compared with unmodified perovskites, the formation of H2O2 in the ORR process is reduced by at least three times when using bifunctional catalysts. Liu S [80] et al. prepared a specific composite material of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) tightly wrapped with perovskite-type CsPbBr3. The synergistic effect of CsPbBr3 and CNTs enhances the pseudocapacitance effect, showing high cycle stability and rate capability. To improve the activity and stability of OER and HER at the same time, Xinhao Wu [81] et al. introduced carbon nanotubes (SrTi0.1Fe0.85Ni0.05O3-δ) on the surface of perovskite in situ. The optimized electrocatalyst obtained at 700°C has higher OER and HER activity than bare perovskite. It has also been proved that the improvement in performance is mainly attributed to the improvement of the charge transfer process, the increase of surface area, and the synergistic effect between the perovskite phase and the CNTs phase. Carbon nanotubes (CNT), with their excellent electrical conductivity, significantly improve the electronic conductivity of perovskite-type oxides and promote the rapid transfer of electrons in the electrocatalytic reaction process. Efficient electron transfer has a direct impact on the activity and reaction rate of the catalyst. Using carbon nanotubes (CNT) as a conductive carrier can improve the overall conductivity of the electrocatalyst, reduce the resistance, and optimize the reaction conditions. By adjusting the length, diameter and surface functional groups of CNT, researchers can optimize its composite form with perovskite-type oxides, improve the flexibility and controllability of the catalyst, and adapt to different catalytic reaction requirements. 4.3 Application of perovskite-MXene composites in electrocatalysis MXene is a two-dimensional layered material composed of transition metal carbides, nitrides and carbonitrides. It has high conductivity, large specific surface area, good charge transfer ability and rich and adjustable surface functional groups [82–84]. MXenes exhibit unique combinations of properties complementary to other two-dimensional materials, such as high conductivity, high Young's modulus, two-dimensional flexibility, and adjustable hydrophilicity. These superior properties combined with simple and scalable synthesis methods make MXenes have attracted much attention in many fields such as energy, materials, environment and biomedicine [85–87]. Due to its rich composition, large specific surface area, and high activity, MXenes are regarded as promising catalysts that support a variety of heterogeneous catalytic and electrocatalytic reactions. Gao G [88] et al. studied several common MXenes materials (such as Ti2C, Nb2C, V2C, TiC2 and Nb3C3) by advanced first-principles calculations. The results show that MXenes with oxygen groups as the terminal exhibit the best electrocatalytic performance (Fig. 9). For the first time, Sun Z [89] et al. prepared a bifunctional hybrid catalyst based on perovskite La0.5Sr0.5CoO3-δ and titanium carbide MXene nanosheets by using high Li ion diffusion titanium carbide in lithium-oxygen battery system. In this way, the reaction kinetics is promoted, and the cycle efficiency of lithium-oxygen batteries is much better than that of titanium carbide, La0.5Sr0.5CoO3-δ and other reported perovskite-based catalysts. Khan [90] et al. prepared a unique composite material by interweaving La0.4Sr0.4Ti0.9Ni0.1O3-δ (LSTN) nanoparticles with two-dimensional Ti3C2Tx (MXene) nanosheets. Due to strong interface interaction and high charge transfer, it not only provides good structural strength for the composite material but also improves the redox activity of the LSTN / MXene 66.67 % catalyst for OER. Perovskite oxide-MnFeO3 nanoparticles embedded in MXene sheets prepared by Sheikh Z A [91] can be used for effective water decomposition and energy storage. The strategy of perovskite oxide nanoparticles hybridizing high-conductivity MXene sheets proposed in this study will be a suitable alternative to potential electrode materials for efficient energy storage/conversion applications. By doping supported metal, non-metal or transition metal compounds, MXenes can be combined with other materials to obtain new electrocatalysts. At the same time, methods such as introducing defects or increasing active sites on the surface of MXenes also effectively improve their electrocatalytic performance. These studies demonstrate the development potential of MXene-based materials in catalysis. Developing a composite material of perovskite and MXene enhances the conductivity of perovskite, which greatly improves the electrochemical performance of the catalyst by virtue of rapid kinetics. 5 Conclusion and outlook Electrocatalytic technology in the energy field has shown a wide range of application potential, but OER and ORR in electrocatalytic reactions require stable and efficient catalysts to improve due to slow kinetic engineering. Among many catalysts, perovskite catalysts stand out, but ordinary perovskite still needs to be modified. The modification methods include crystal structure adjustment, doping regulation, nano-treatment, and carbon material compounding. Compared with other modification methods of perovskite materials, the introduction of carbon materials into the preparation of perovskite-type oxide electrocatalysts can increase the contact area between the reactants and the catalyst and provide more active sites, thereby significantly improving the electrocatalytic performance. The design of this carbon-perovskite composite opens up a new direction for fuel cell research, enhances the catalyst's functionality, stability and cost-effectiveness, and provides a new idea for developing efficient, stable and economical electrocatalytic materials. With an in-depth understanding of its composite mechanism, researchers can design more efficient electrocatalysts to promote the development of sustainable energy solutions. This material combination helps to improve the energy conversion efficiency of fuel cells and reduce costs, laying the foundation for wide application. However, the preparation of perovskite/carbon composites often requires specific processes to exploit the advantages of the two materials. Therefore, choosing the appropriate preparation method, sharing a variety of modification methods, and compounding with carbon materials with excellent performance can make the electrocatalytic activity of the material better and the stability higher. This idea can provide a reference for subsequent related research. CRediT authorship contribution statement Yue Wang: Writing – review & editing, Writing – original draft. coredata.dc:description: Perovskite/carbon composites have received extensive attention in the field of electrocatalysis due to their outstanding catalytic activity and good electrical conductivity. These materials have the advantages of structural stability and low cost and exhibit excellent catalytic performance in electrocatalytic reactions. In this paper, we first review the progress of research on perovskite oxide materials. We discussed its modification strategies in electrocatalysis, including crystal structure adjustment, doping regulation, nano-treatment and carbon material composite. Then, the specific application examples of three leading perovskite/carbon composites in electrocatalytic reactions are summarized, showing these composites' good performance and high efficiency in the catalytic process. Finally, the development trend of perovskite/carbon composites as electrocatalyst carriers is comprehensively summarized and prospected, which points out the future research direction for promoting its application and development in clean energy.
coredata.dc:title: Research progress of perovskite/carbon composites in the field of electrocatalysis
